trial_identification.studytitle: spinal anesthesia decreases ocular pressure in patients with leg surgery
trial_identification.scientifictitle: The Effects Of Tourniquet On Intraocular Pressure During Lower Extremity Surgery Under Spinal Anesthesia

interventions.interventions: measurement of intraocular pressure in patients who went on lower extremity surgery under spinal anesthesia (with or without tourniquet),Tuorniquet were used in 30 patients and were not used in other 30 patients.Participants observed once immediately prior to anaesthesia, and again 3 different times during surgery and at the end of surgery.The use of tourniquet was decided by surgeon.
interventions.comparator: Comparison of intraocular pressure measurement in patients with or without tourniquet

primaryOutcome.outcome: Change in intraocular pressure(IOP) with spinal anesthesia with or without tourniquet was assessed with tonometer(Reichert Tono-Pen AVIA-Registered Trademark' Applanation Tonometer).

secondaryOutcome.outcome: effect of tourniquet on intraocular pressure during spinal anesthesia, intraocular pressure was measured with contact tonometer, patients were informed before the measurement.
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: IOP was recorded 5 minutes before spinal anesthesia (T1) , 5 minutes after spinal anesthesia (T2), when operation started (T3)(5 minutes after tourniquet inflated in tourniquet group and 5 minutes after T2 in group without tourniquet) and at the end of the surgery (T4).

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: After approval by Ethics Committee and written informed consent from the patients, ASA physical status I-II patients Aged 18-65 years Elective lower extremity surgery were included in the study patients who were operated under spinal anesthesia
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Chronic diseases except regular hypertension Known allergies to any anesthetic drugs used in the study Eye disease or surgery in the medical history Any contrendications for spinal anesthesia Estimated tourniquet time more 120 min

trial_design.statisticalmethods: .Student T test was used for the normal ranged data Mann Whitney U test was used for data that was except of the normal range. Categorical data was compared with Chi-square test. p<0.05 was accepted as significant.Data was analyzed using SPSS 16 software.

sponsorship.primarysponsoraddress: Ardicli Mahallesi, Ismet Pasa Cd., 42250 Selcuklu/Konya TURKEY

fundingsource.fundingaddress: Ardicli Mahallesi, Ismet Pasa Cd., 42250 Selcuklu/Konya TURKEY

ethicsAndSummary.summary: Background: There are many factors which may effect intraocular pressure.Tourniquet, which is used in extremity surgery, also effect intraoculary pressure.There many studies about the effect of tourniquet on intraocular pressure, that were performed in patients went on general anesthesia.There was no study about the effect of tourniquet on intraoculary pressure that was performed in patients who go on spinal anethesia. Material and methods : Intraocular pressure was measured on patients who went on lower extremity surgery with or without tourniquet under spinal anesthesia.Measurements were performed before spinal anethesia, 5 minutes after spinal anethesia, 5 minutes after surgery started and at the end of the surgery.All measurements were performed in the supine position.Mean arterial blood pressure, heart rate, intraocular pressure and bleeding volumes were recorded. Results: In both groups, 5 minutes after spinal anesthesia intraocular pressure measurements were lower than the baseline intraocular pressure measurements.However, the measurements which were performed after tourniquet insufflation were higher than the baseline. Conclusion:Intraocular pressure decreases in patient who went on spinal anesthesia but, tourquet insufflation increases intraocular pressure also in patients who went lower extremity surgery with tourniquet.
